quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I feel like only 30 to 40% of what I've learned in the last 15 to 20 years of being in growth transfers here because we just need to invest in such bigger bets, and innovate, and create new growth loops here, everybody and their mother is starting a vibe coding business nowadays, and we need to figure out how to be ahead of them. And to be ahead of them is not optimization of the problem, it's reinvention of the solution.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A contrarian growth model for AI markets: winning requires reinvention and new loops, not incremental optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I just feel like I usually spend maybe 5% innovating on growth in my previous roles, right now, I'm spending 95% innovating on growth, and only 5% on optimization.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A practical resource-allocation heuristic for AI growth teams: shift dramatically from optimization to innovation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: One of our biggest strategy is building in public, and it's coupled with employee socials, founder-led socials. And another one is giving your product away a lot, this is part of our growth secret sauce. You have to remove the barrier of entry.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Two concrete, repeatable levers—build in public and aggressively reduce friction via generosity—to drive adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If somebody, one of our users stands up and say, hey, I'm going to have a hackathon at my work on Lovable, can you give us some free credits to play with? Why would we prevent a person who wants to do all of the marketing and activating for us from using us? We're like, take it, how much do you need?
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A specific example of turning users into distribution by subsidizing high-leverage moments (e.g., workplace hackathons).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The only way to create a word of mouth loop is just to blow their socks off.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable standard for virality: word-of-mouth comes from outsized product delight, not tactics alone.

quotes.topic_title: Newsletter offer and Sponsor Break
quotes.text: WorkOS turns those deal blockers into drop-in APIs, with a modern developer platform built specifically for B2B SaaS.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical approach to accelerating enterprise sales by productizing common enterprise requirements as reusable APIs.

quotes.topic_title: Newsletter offer and Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Whether you're a seed stage startup trying to land your first enterprise customer, or a unicorn expanding globally, WorkOS is the fastest path to becoming enterprise-ready and unlocking growth.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable growth lever: becoming enterprise-ready earlier to unlock larger deals and expansion.

quotes.topic_title: Newsletter offer and Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They're essentially Stripe for enterprise features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that frames enterprise-readiness features as a standardized infrastructure layer you can outsource.

quotes.topic_title: Newsletter offer and Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Don't just show up to reviews with docs and ideas, arrive with working prototypes that demonstrate real functionality.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable advice for speeding alignment and decision-making by replacing abstract plans with tangible prototypes.

quotes.topic_title: Newsletter offer and Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you can dream it, you can ship it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concise, motivating principle emphasizing rapid execution from idea to implementation.

quotes.topic_title: Lovable’s scale: $200M ARR in a year
quotes.text: So, for us, we've hit over $200 million in annual recurring revenue before we even hit our one-year milestone since being launched.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A concrete scale datapoint that anchors the discussion in measurable outcomes (ARR and timeline).

quotes.topic_title: Lovable’s scale: $200M ARR in a year
quotes.text: Because we had our 100 million in end of July, and just four months later we were at 200 million.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Shows compounding growth dynamics via specific milestone timing that practitioners can use to calibrate growth expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Lovable’s scale: $200M ARR in a year
quotes.text: So, I want to make sure that people don't all of a sudden set this as a benchmark for success because it should never be.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A contrarian warning against misusing outlier companies as universal benchmarks when setting goals and evaluating performance.

quotes.topic_title: Lovable’s scale: $200M ARR in a year
quotes.text: Recurring $200 million a year is absurd.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the importance of distinguishing ARR from non-recurring revenue when comparing companies and categories.

quotes.topic_title: Lovable’s scale: $200M ARR in a year
quotes.text: So, when you're setting yourself as a benchmark, so you know which benchmarks you actually to use, and whether Lovable is the benchmark that you should be using.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Encourages a deliberate benchmarking methodology—choosing comparables based on market/category dynamics rather than hype.

quotes.topic_title: Who pays, use cases, and retention reality
quotes.text:
Because when I think about software, I think about it, I talked to John Cutler actually, and he gave me this framework that is completely stuck in my mind, of software always goes through capabilities stage first, so what is possible to actually create with this?

Then, it needs to transition into value, of how is it that am I going to get value out of this? And then you can start thinking about scaling it, of which aspects of my life and my work that can actually go in?
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A practical product adoption framework (capabilities → value → scaling) for diagnosing where users are and what to build/market next.

quotes.topic_title: Who pays, use cases, and retention reality
quotes.text: And the beautiful thing here is that what you can do changes every month to three months. So, you constantly need to come back and you need to see what has changed.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Highlights a cadence-based retention driver in fast-moving AI products: frequent capability shifts create natural re-engagement loops.

quotes.topic_title: Who pays, use cases, and retention reality
quotes.text: And then there's actually engagement retention as well, because that is the leading indicator for how your paid retention is going to look like.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A clear metric hierarchy: prioritize engagement retention as the upstream signal that predicts revenue retention.

quotes.topic_title: Who pays, use cases, and retention reality
quotes.text: Our NDR is quite good because when people build, they want to buy more credits to build.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Connects expansion revenue directly to core product behavior (building), implying usage-based monetization can drive strong NDR.

quotes.topic_title: Who pays, use cases, and retention reality
quotes.text: we don't optimize for revenue at all. In fact, internally, we have a lot of discussions about how can we give more products away, how can we reduce our revenue growth rate by just getting more paid subscribers, more users using Lovable, to just get bigger share of the market.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A counterintuitive growth strategy: deliberately deprioritize revenue optimization to maximize adoption and market share.

quotes.topic_title: Why Elena threw out the old growth playbook
quotes.text: When I started at Lovable, the one thing to me that was very clear is that this company was growing like crazy before I joined.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Highlights a key diagnostic: in surging AI categories, the job is often to remove friction and scale what’s already working rather than “create” growth from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: Why Elena threw out the old growth playbook
quotes.text: So, yes, we're at the right place, we're at the right time, but we're also in really fast moving waters, and the demand that is coming to us, we need to capture it mostly, we don't need to generate a lot of it yet.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Reframes growth strategy from demand generation to demand capture when the market is pulling hard.

quotes.topic_title: Why Elena threw out the old growth playbook
quotes.text: But at the same time, it comes with the really big downfalls of we're not in control of a lot of our growth.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning: hypergrowth can be externally driven (e.g., word of mouth), reducing how much levers-and-metrics optimization can actually steer outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Why Elena threw out the old growth playbook
quotes.text: But when I'm thinking about the patterns here, and what I have to unlearn, I feel like only 30 to 40% of what I've learned in the last 15 to 20 years of being in growth transfers here.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A concrete transfer-rate heuristic practitioners can use to anticipate how much of “classic growth” applies in fast-moving AI categories.

quotes.topic_title: Why Elena threw out the old growth playbook
quotes.text: But the rest of it, honestly, it doesn't feel like it even matters anymore, because we just need to invest in such bigger bets, and innovate, and create new growth loops here, as opposed to trying to optimize it to the moon and beyond, which I usually be focused on in a scaled business like this.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Shifts the growth mandate from incremental optimization to inventing new loops and making larger, riskier bets in AI-native markets.

quotes.topic_title: Growth team builds product: features over funnel tweaks
quotes.text: Here, what I find is that optimizations are just not worth our time.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Contrasts traditional growth funnel tuning with a strategy of deprioritizing micro-optimizations in fast-moving markets.

quotes.topic_title: Growth team builds product: features over funnel tweaks
quotes.text: And to be ahead of them is not optimization of the problem, it's reinvention of the solution.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for competing in crowded categories by building fundamentally new solutions rather than polishing existing flows.

quotes.topic_title: Growth team builds product: features over funnel tweaks
quotes.text: So, I just feel like I usually spend maybe 5%, maybe 10% if I'm lucky, innovating on growth, in my roles, in my previous roles, right now, I'm spending 95% innovating on growth, and only 5% on optimization.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A concrete allocation heuristic (innovation vs. optimization) practitioners can use to recalibrate growth team priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Growth team builds product: features over funnel tweaks
quotes.text: Yeah. And for example, we on growth team launched integration with Shopify, to enable e-commerce use case, because we're like, hey, there's already people trying to come in and do it, Shopify was open for integration with us, let's go lean into it so people can vibe code their storefronts.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Specific example of a growth team shipping core product capability (Shopify integration) to unlock a new use case and loop.

quotes.topic_title: Growth team builds product: features over funnel tweaks
quotes.text: So, the work fundamentally, I feel like has gotten deeper into product, and deeper into actual core product functionality, as opposed to just being a smoothing surface on the outer layers.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Defines a modern growth operating model where growth builds core product/agent workflows rather than only optimizing surface-level UX.

quotes.topic_title: Building in public and shipping velocity as marketing
quotes.text: But at the same time, what's really important to us is to maintain noise in the market. And that noise in the market happens by us shipping every day, every other day, multiple times per day and just talking about it constantly.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A concrete operating model: use high-frequency shipping + social amplification to stay top-of-mind.

quotes.topic_title: Building in public and shipping velocity as marketing
quotes.text: Interestingly enough, it's actually works fantastic resurrection strategy, because people are like, "Oh, there's more things here. I need to go check it out."
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Counterintuitive idea that constant shipping can revive dormant interest without traditional campaigns.

quotes.topic_title: Building in public and shipping velocity as marketing
quotes.text: So instead of sending newsletters to say, "Here's the market trends or here's the user stories," people are literally logging into their social to say, "Okay, what has Lovable shipped now?"
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Reframes social feeds as the primary re-engagement channel when shipping cadence is high.

quotes.topic_title: Building in public and shipping velocity as marketing
quotes.text: Velocity of shipping is our number one core value in development team. So we do anything and everything to just keep it going up, up, up and into the right.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable cultural principle: explicitly make shipping velocity the top engineering value to drive growth.

quotes.topic_title: Building in public and shipping velocity as marketing
quotes.text: We call them product engineers, and they have to go and they have to announce the thing that they've shipped. It doesn't just funnel through marketing.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Operational tactic: push product marketing distribution to engineers to scale “building in public” without a huge marketing team.

quotes.topic_title: Marketing shifts: SEO to social and influencer dominance
quotes.text: If you ask me what's your organic marketing strategy right now, to me it's all about social. Which is what is my CEO posting? What is my team posting? What is my creator economy doing? Influencer marketing, and across all of the social platforms.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Reframes “organic” from SEO-first to social-first, with specific levers practitioners can operationalize (founder, team, creators).

quotes.topic_title: Marketing shifts: SEO to social and influencer dominance
quotes.text: But you cannot just have ChatGPT write your copy and post it, you need to show personality. There needs to be humanity that it goes through it.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for social content: authenticity and human voice are now a competitive requirement, not a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Marketing shifts: SEO to social and influencer dominance
quotes.text: The only way to create a word of mouth loop is just to blow their socks off when they actually experience your product.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A simple mental model for word-of-mouth: it’s primarily a product experience problem, not a marketing tactics problem.

quotes.topic_title: Marketing shifts: SEO to social and influencer dominance
quotes.text: We put all of the brand work actually into our product. When you think about Lovable, people think about a brand, but we don't have a brand marketing team yet.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Counterintuitive operating model: build brand through product interactions rather than a dedicated brand marketing function.

quotes.topic_title: Marketing shifts: SEO to social and influencer dominance
quotes.text: Interestingly enough, influencer marketing is 10 times bigger for us than paid social.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Concrete channel performance data point that challenges the default assumption that paid social is the primary scalable lever.

quotes.topic_title: Lovable as a brand: delight, humanity, and experience
quotes.text: But I actually see it as part of growth strategy to make sure that that brand shines through every single interaction.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Reframes brand as a core growth lever by embedding it into all product touchpoints, not just marketing.

quotes.topic_title: Lovable as a brand: delight, humanity, and experience
quotes.text: But the way to stand out in the super crowded category is to create experiences that speak to people.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable differentiation strategy: compete on experience and emotional resonance when the market is crowded.

quotes.topic_title: Lovable as a brand: delight, humanity, and experience
quotes.text: And I think that we're actually moving to the new era of software that needs to feel human, that people want to interact with, not just utility of it.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A mental model for product strategy: “human” interaction becomes a requirement as utility becomes commoditized.

quotes.topic_title: Lovable as a brand: delight, humanity, and experience
quotes.text: Because cost of software is coming down so much to develop that we now can actually invest into emotional feel of that software, as opposed to only just focus on creating the utility out of it.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Counterintuitive shift: cheaper building costs move the battleground from functionality to emotional experience.

quotes.topic_title: Lovable as a brand: delight, humanity, and experience
quotes.text: So your designer has to be one of your first hires now in startups.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Concrete hiring advice that operationalizes the “experience is the differentiator” thesis.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for speed: passion, autonomy, and work trials
quotes.text: It's somebody who is extremely passionate about their job.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Reframes “best talent” away from pedigree and toward intrinsic motivation as the core hiring filter for speed without chaos.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for speed: passion, autonomy, and work trials
quotes.text: It's their hobby. They love to work. They have fire in their belly. This is not a paycheck for them, they want to do this for some ulterior reason. This is the biggest opportunity of their life, so this is global maximum against any other opportunities that are in front of them at the moment.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Defines a concrete “passion bar” (work as hobby + global-max opportunity) that practitioners can use to screen for intensity and commitment.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for speed: passion, autonomy, and work trials
quotes.text: the other two skills, by the way, that are super important is high agency and high autonomy. I can figure out things that are tangential to me that I don't need other specialties, so to speak. I don't need a marketer to go launch something, I can go figure it out. And I have high agency, I can go do it myself. I'm going to own it all the way from start to finish.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Offers a practical competency model (high agency + high autonomy) for avoiding coordination bottlenecks while shipping fast.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for speed: passion, autonomy, and work trials
quotes.text: So trial work to see them in action for a couple of days. We pay them as part of the work trial. We have some probation periods that we start people on, because this company is not for everybody.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: A concrete hiring methodology—paid work trials plus probation—to validate fit for extreme pace before committing long-term.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for speed: passion, autonomy, and work trials
quotes.text: So we try to be very upfront with how things are and how chaotic they are, and we prioritize people that don't look for clarity. We can create clarity out of chaos because it is absolutely chaotic otherwise.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Counterintuitive recruiting criterion: select for people who thrive without pre-existing clarity, enabling speed in high-change environments.

quotes.topic_title: Minimum Lovable Product and collapsed feedback cycles
quotes.text: I call it minimum lovable product. It shouldn't be minimal viable product anymore. Viability is left back in 2010s. Now it's minimal lovable product. That's the only thing that matters.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Reframes MVP into a sharper product bar for AI-era markets: optimize for delight/love, not mere viability.

quotes.topic_title: Minimum Lovable Product and collapsed feedback cycles
quotes.text: Yeah. Well, it's the feedback cycle. It's just completely collapsed. You can go from idea to some product that is functioning to user feedback within a day if you want to, depending on how fast that you want to run or how complex the product is.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable operating model shift: use AI to compress build-test-learn loops from months to as little as a day.

quotes.topic_title: Minimum Lovable Product and collapsed feedback cycles
quotes.text: Before, it would just take so many more steps from user research to the design sprints, to prioritizing an engineering roadmap, to build something minimal and viable to actually test to little long testing cycles. Now it's just like, "Boom, let's go."
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Contrasts legacy product development process with an AI-enabled rapid prototyping cadence that removes intermediate gates.

quotes.topic_title: Minimum Lovable Product and collapsed feedback cycles
quotes.text: For missions, it took us a couple of weeks to vibe code it to the point to where... I have a full-time vibe coder on my team. He's amazing.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Concrete example of resourcing and timeline: a dedicated “vibe coder” can prototype a feature to testable quality in weeks (or faster).

quotes.topic_title: What is a full-time vibe coder?
quotes.text: This is a new job role that is actually popping up here and there.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Highlights that “vibe coder” is emerging as a distinct role practitioners may need to hire for or define.

quotes.topic_title: What is a full-time vibe coder?
quotes.text: because I see vibe coding as a skill being added to a lot of job descriptions. For designers, for product managers, for marketers, which I think is a really interesting shift.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Suggests vibe coding is becoming a cross-functional skill, not limited to engineering, changing how teams staff and upskill.

quotes.topic_title: What is a full-time vibe coder?
quotes.text: Finally, Excel can move over. We have a new skill to add that is super empowering and not-
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Memorable framing that positions vibe coding as a new baseline productivity skill akin to (or replacing) Excel.

quotes.topic_title: What is a full-time vibe coder?
quotes.text: vibe coder, so his name is Lazar and he actually was chief of staff in his previous role so he's not technical at all.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Concrete example that challenges the assumption that vibe coding requires a traditional technical background.

quotes.topic_title: What is a full-time vibe coder?
quotes.text: He was user of all of the vibe coding tools, Lovable included.
quotes.speaker: Elena Verna
quotes.context: Actionable hint that proficiency comes from hands-on use of multiple vibe-coding tools rather than formal engineering training.
